message.content:
cs.DC, cs.CR, cs.DS, cs.NI, cs.SY. 

The paper discusses committee selection mechanisms in distributed consensus algorithms, which are typically studied in the Distributed, Parallel, and Cluster Computing (cs.DC) sub-category. The paper also discusses the guarantees on communication complexity, resource usage, and fairness, which are typically studied in the Cryptography and Security (cs.CR) sub-category. The paper uses simulations to verify claims, which falls under the Data Structures and Algorithms (cs.DS) sub-category. The paper also discusses the necessary and sufficient conditions for Byzantine agreement, which is typically studied in the Networking and Internet Architecture (cs.NI) sub-category. Finally, the paper discusses the existence of a "statistical taxonomy" of committee selection mechanisms, which falls under the Systems and Control (cs.SY) sub-category.
